title: Mosaic magazine typefaces - Raleigh, Auto (still one to identify!)
content:
This is a scan from 121 magazine that just arrived the other day. I don’t remember seeing these fonts before. They are used all through the magazine, sometimes copy text is set in the serif.  
The sans has strange Äs, I think, is that very common?

| Attachment | Size |
| --- | --- |
| [mosaic.png](http://web.archive.org/web/20081030030847/http:/typophile.com/files/mosaic.png) | 201.04 KB |

 [‹ (x) "no star" square sans - Eurostile {Rainer}](http://web.archive.org/web/20081030030847/http:/typophile.com/node/34891 "Go to previous forum topic") [(x) American Red Cross of Massachusetts Bay - Arial {Florian Hardwig} ›](http://web.archive.org/web/20081030030847/http:/typophile.com/node/34893 "Go to next forum topic")
author: mili

comments.content:
Mosaic and the first two lines is Raleigh.  
 [http://www.myfonts.com/fonts/bitstream/raleigh/raleigh/](http://web.archive.org/web/20081030030847/http:/www.myfonts.com/fonts/bitstream/raleigh/raleigh/ "http://www.myfonts.com/fonts/bitstream/raleigh/raleigh/")
Thank you, Pieter! I find the “o”s interesting and unusual.
think the one at the bottom is auto by underware
Good one, James. Two down, one to go.

Well, I took this last one as a challenge, and I think it has defeated me. The counter on the P and R is too big for anything I can find. The J, K, C and S are also hard to find in combination anywhere; and of course the low Ä is really _not_ common at all.

I pretty much hunted the condensed sansserifs at MyFonts, and the best I could come up with were Storm’s [’Ohrada’](http://web.archive.org/web/20081030030847/http:/www.myfonts.com/fonts/storm/ohrada/), Berthold’s [’AG Condensed’](http://web.archive.org/web/20081030030847/http:/www.myfonts.com/fonts/berthold/akzidenz-grotesk-bq/medium-condensed/) and [’Silverscreen’](http://web.archive.org/web/20081030030847/http:/www.myfonts.com/fonts/typeart/silverscreen/), from TypeArt.

This is a good mystery, because condensed sans faces are used a lot, but I am coming to the conclusion that this is from an obscure source — maybe a small European foundry.

- Mike Yanega

Thank you for trying, Mike!  
That low Ä was the thing that really caught my attention, not too keen on it, to be honest. It looks very strange in words with double-Ä, and that’s not unusual in Finnish, as you can see in this nonsense sentence:

“kääntäisitkö äänilevyn kääntöpuolen ääriasentoon?”

The nex issue of the magazine just arrived with the mystery font used in a headline. Is it any easier to recognise in bigger size?

 ![](http://web.archive.org/web/20081030030847im_/http:/typophile.com/files/seniori_6595.jpg)
